image.altText: A black and white collage including a man in sunglasses and headlines relating to child sexual abuse.

items.synopsis: For decades, Victoria's education department shuffled paedophile teachers to new schools where they abused more schoolchildren. As the historical scale of the scourge in the Victorian public system becomes clearer, there are calls for the state to confront the issue with a broader inquiry.

title.children: 'The cover-up was comprehensive': How the Victorian Education Department's historical child sexual abuse scandal was hidden for decades

image.altText: A man and woman unload bales of hay from a truck

items.synopsis: Farmers in New South Wales are concerned about the prospect of the state plunging into another drought, saying there has been an alarmingly rapid return to dry conditions.

title.children: 'A major drought event is forming': Why farmers fear history is repeating itself

image.altText: Army cadets in full camouflage, holding guns during a demonstration in front of an audience in a field.

items.synopsis: The federal opposition says an allegation students could not wear uniforms on Friday is "coercive" and "overtly political".

title.children: ADF Academy cadets claim they were pressured to remove uniforms for Wear It Purple Day

image.altText: A composite of Dmitry Utkin, Vladimir Putin and Yevgeny Prigozhin

items.synopsis: Whether the apparent downing of a Wagner plane stacked with Putin's enemies was an accident or an assassination, Russia's president reaps the rewards. This is what we know about the crash that changed everything.

title.children: In Putin's Russia, nothing is as it seems. But did he just unleash his own Night of the Long Knives?

image.altText: A wooden boat sits in the ocean near the horizon, with green and brown sludge on the surface near foreground

items.synopsis: For months, the bodies of young migrants have been washing up on the beaches of Tunisia's Mediterranean coast. They are among thousands of sub-Saharan Africans fleeing extreme poverty and war, taking desperate journeys to escape.

title.children: Desperation is turning the Mediterranean into a watery grave. This is what the ABC found on a secret trip

image.altText: pa Chantelle Anderson and gigi

items.synopsis: As Australia tries to control the risk of rabies from the importation of cats and dogs, these pet owners say the country's strict policy has cost them time, money and in one case, their dog's health.

title.children: Chantelle doesn't think her dog Gigi will ever recover from the six months she spent in boarding quarantine

image.altText: cctv vision after the moment of impact

items.synopsis: A man has been charged over a crash that killed two young boys in the Sydney suburb of Monterey.

title.children: Driver charged over Sydney crash that killed two boys, aged nine and 10

image.altText: Baby singing with parent

items.synopsis: We make up endless silly, sweet, spontaneous songs to sing to our children. Have you ever thought about why?

title.children: The sweet silly songs we sing to our kids aren't just for fun — they change their brain

image.altText: GFXb_Paretophone_HACK_Digital-25

items.synopsis: The number of charities revealing their donors have had personal information leaked to the dark web is growing, as the tally of Australians implicated exceeds 50,000.

title.children: Donor financial information leaked in attack on charity sector

image.altText: Archival picture of Robert Menzies escorted amid an angry crowd of strikers at the Dalfram Dispute

items.synopsis: At the national Labor conference, Pat Conroy asked if those opposed to the nuclear-powered submarine deal were on the side of "Pig Iron Bob Menzies". The question has dumbfounded those who know the nickname was coined during an iconic protest for peace.

title.children: Conroy's 'Pig Iron Bob' barb falls flat in Labor heartland

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: The Spanish Football Association accuses Jenni Hermoso of lying about her response to a kiss from president Luis Rubiales and threatens legal action, as FIFA suspends the under-fire Spanish president.

title.children: Luis Rubiales suspended by FIFA as Spanish FA threatens legal action

items.synopsis: In an offbeat way to relax and find inner calm, these yogis are enjoying baby goat cuddles, "lots of laughing" and even a few "nibbles" in between their poses.

title.children: Miniature goat yoga brings stress release and 'so much joy' to small country town

image.altText: Woman holds 2 barbies in front of huge collection of others in boxes

items.synopsis: In Russia, Barbie fans will finally get the chance to see the blockbuster film on the big screen, including this avid collector of 12,000 dolls.

title.children: This diehard fan says Barbie inspires her to 'be anything', even in wartime Russia

image.altText: A man in a green shirt on a couch next to a dog, smiling.

items.synopsis: Grame Hopf has dedicated more than half a century to fostering the most "challenging" cases, including a murderer, violent drug addicts and sex offenders.

title.children: A stranger's act of kindness was 'the start of life' for this street kid turned foster father

image.altText: A faded red and blue cargo ship next to a tug boat in the ocean.

items.synopsis: There's a backlog of vessels waiting to cross one of the world's crucial maritime passageways.

title.children: Why is the Panama Canal drying up and what does it mean for global shipping?

image.altText: A person shopping at Australian grocery store, with a basket full of sparkling water, fruits and vegetables.

items.synopsis: Everything we consume contains energy our bodies use to move, grow and maintain health. To work out how much energy is in different foods and drinks, we need to first look at a few core concepts.

title.children: Calories and kilojoules: How do we know the energy content of food, and how accurate are labels?

image.altText: A plastic-gloved hand holds a string of plastic vials that have red liquid at the bottom

items.synopsis: Australian scientists look to overseas providers of an important but increasingly hard-to-get abattoir by-product.

title.children: A vital ingredient for cancer research is in tight supply with the price rising

image.altText: A selfie of a serious man with shaved hair next to his large brown dog.

items.synopsis: The 44-year-old suffered injuries to both legs during a "sustained and prolonged" attack.

title.children: Community raises funds for Port Macquarie man after shark attack

image.altText: Nina Kennedy and Katie Moon look at medals

items.synopsis: Joint world pole vault champion Katie Moon hit back at her critics after the American says she was called "shameful" and "pathetic" after sharing the gold medal with Australian Nina Kennedy.

title.children: Pole vault champion hits out after being called 'pathetic' after sharing gold

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin sits at a desk with his hands on it.

items.synopsis: The Russian president signed the decree bringing in the change with immediate effect after the Kremlin said Western suggestions that Mr Prigozhin had been killed on its orders were an "absolute lie".

title.children: Putin orders Wagner fighters to sign oath of allegiance after Prigozhin's purported demise

image.altText: A still shot from CCTV of the elderly man being physically assaulted by the motorcyclist.

items.synopsis: A 70-year-old man has been charged over what police allege was an unprovoked attack on an elderly man south of Perth.

title.children: Elderly man punched, kicked in alleged road rage attack south of Perth

image.altText: A window shows a pink sun set over an airplane.

items.synopsis: It's the sneaky travel hack that's been used by savvy consumers for years. Here's what we know about skiplagging.

title.children: Airlines are cracking down on this travel hack and one website is in the crosshairs

image.altText: A wide shot of the hotel. There's palm trees in front.

items.synopsis: It's the end of an era for Hotel Theodore, the only pub in Queensland owned entirely by the community.

title.children: Queensland's only community-owned pub up for sale after financial struggle

image.altText: Anxiety and stress generic

items.synopsis: The parasympathetic nervous system via the vagus nerves is the counterbalance to our stress response. It makes us more calm, relaxed and sociable, writes Theresa Larkin.

title.children: The vagus nerve could hold the key to a mental and physical reset

image.altText: Thorpe sits at a senate bench looking towards the camera, an Aboriginal flag tattoo visible on her arm.

items.synopsis: Federal police have charged a 30-year-old man for allegedly making and distributing a video to threaten independent senator Lidia Thorpe.

title.children: Man facing court over alleged violent threats against senator Lidia Thorpe

image.altText: DJ Just Dizle standing outside, leaning on a pole, in front of a river, wearing a white t-shirt and gold chain

items.synopsis: International DJ Just Dizle has zigzagged across Europe, the Americas and Africa on a mission to bring a smile to people's faces with his new song Feelin Alive.

title.children: The DJ who travelled three continents to make people smile

image.altText: An Adelaide Thunderbirds Super Netball player holds the ball during a game against the Queensland Thunderbirds.

items.synopsis: A blaze, suspected to have been set by arsonists, ripped through and destroyed multiple homes in the Kingston area, leaving up to 50 other people either homeless or displaced, according to local media.

title.children: Thunderbirds champion Latanya Wilson left homeless after house fire in Jamaica

image.altText: Two Western Bulldogs players smile as one points his finger in celebration after a goal.

items.synopsis: The Western Bulldogs are still alive for finals after a fiercely-fought win over Geelong at Kardinia Park, the Eagles will finish with the wooden spoon - and pick one - and the Lions finally seal second spot and two home finals.

title.children: Bulldogs stay alive, Eagles take wooden spoon, Lions wrap up top two

image.altText: F1 driver Daniel Ricciardo walks through pitlane, in his racing suit, wearing headphones

items.synopsis: The Australian was ruled out of Sunday's Dutch Grand Prix, but he could miss more races.

title.children: Ricciardo facing possible surgery on broken wrist, Verstappen on pole chasing F1 record

image.altText: Ryan Papenhuyzen runs onto the field for an NRL game as Melbourne Storm fans cheer behind him.

items.synopsis: The Melbourne Storm celebrate the return of fullback Ryan Papenhuyzen after 405 days sidelined by a shattered knee, but an injury to another star could throw a monkey wrench in their plans for a staged comeback.

title.children: 'I haven't heard noise like that for a while': After more than a year, Ryan Papenhuyzen is finally back in the NRL

image.altText: A man with grey stubble looks at the camera as he stands among a group of people.

items.synopsis: The director of the British Museum says he will step down after admitting to failings in an investigation into the theft of items from its collection.

title.children: British Museum director quits over 'failings' in investigation into stolen treasures

image.altText: A graphic image of a broken "for lease" sign against a background of grid paper. A line of cartoon people run behind it.

items.synopsis: Across the housing sector, from renters to real estate agents and landlords, there's broad agreement that Australia's rental system needs an overhaul — and fast. The problem is, few agree on what that change should look like.

title.children: 'This has been a long time coming': How the cracks in Australia's rental market were revealed

image.altText: A composite image of a young woman on the left ice-skating and on the right on horseback.

items.synopsis: When people meet Rudi McEwin with dirt on her face at outback campdrafts they'd never pick her former hobby was figure-skating, but she says there are more similarities between the sports than you might expect.

title.children: Swapping ice-skates for horseback, Rudi found a hobby that's just as 'thrilling'

image.altText: Ken Henry #4

items.synopsis: The latest Intergenerational Report paints a picture of an Australian landscape working in a very different way to ones we have seen in the past. There is no room for blank spots, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Australia is facing an intergenerational 'tragedy' that demands big picture discussions about the future

image.altText: A woman walks down an aisle of a supermarket. Products on shelves either side of her.

items.synopsis: Supermarket theft is on the rise, costing the industry hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The crime wave is not just hitting Australia — it's proving to be a major global issue as inflation pressures bite and organised gangs seize opportunities.

title.children: Supermarkets roll out high tech to catch shoplifters as cost-of-living pressures bite
